channel.title: C# Hash Check A critical question about?
channel.description:
![1|500x361](upload://55EoUig4GJQHlfzhE5XmjqfLDQH.png)
We need to add hash before activating hash check, but is there a program for C# where we can drag the program and get the hash code?

item.source: C# Hash Check A critical question about?

item.title: C# Hash Check A critical question about?
item.dc:creator: mak
item.description:
The version is checked before the hash is checked, as seen here KeyAuth-Source-Code/index.php at 42075d66929ebf497acd9e0c3eddfa55e7df168f · KeyAuth/KeyAuth-Source-Code · GitHub

Meaning, if you run the old program with outdated version number, the API will return error saying version failure, and the person will be instructed to download the download link set, which should be your program with the latest version. If you don’t set, it will notify the user the version is outdated and that no download link was supplied.

Then, as long as you reset hash and run the latest program right after, or manually add hash of latest program to dashboard in app settings, when you run latest program, you will not get hash check failure message.

I just tested this. I built c++ example with version 1.0. I renamed to old_example.exe after compiling to ensure it didn’t get overwritten by the next compile. I then changed the version in the c++ code to 1.1, and changed the version on keyauth dashboard in app settings to 1.1. I compiled the code again, and before running the latest file I compiled, I click the Reset Program Hash button in app settings on dashboard. I then ran the latest file, it worked, no hash check issues. Yes I turned on hash checking for this test. I then ran the old file with the outdated version, it automatically opened the download link I set on dashboard. And I tried removing the download link set on dashboard, and it then showed me the error saying no download link set.

So, it’s working fine on my end. If you’re using c# example, make sure it has the code checking for invalidver. It’s in the examples, though perhaps you removed it on accident.

Read full topic
item.source: C# Hash Check A critical question about?

item.title: C# Hash Check A critical question about?
item.dc:creator: ByYasin
item.description:
Abastrax:

So if theres a new version and the new hash is saved its just gonna Auto-update and not give a hash error.

So if theres a new version and the new hash is saved its just gonna Auto-update and not give a hash error.
You replied as.

But it’s the opposite of what you said, so it doesn’t get an update because it checks the hash first.

Read full topic

item.title: C# Hash Check A critical question about?
item.dc:creator: Abastrax
item.description:
It checks for updates before it checks for the hash.

So if theres a new version and the new hash is saved its just gonna Auto-update and not give a hash error.

Read full topic
item.source: C# Hash Check A critical question about?

item.title: C# Hash Check A critical question about?
item.dc:creator: ByYasin
item.description:
@Abastrax
In addition, there is an answer I have to ask and I expect from you professionals, now I understand that it receives hash automatically, but when I open a recompiled .exe, it gives a hash mismatch error. By clicking on the “reset program hash” button on the keyauth panel and running the newly compiled .exe, it automatically saves the hash of the newly compiled program and now it opens. sorry it’s been long.

So, when this is the case, users who use the previous version will get priority auto update because they open the previous old .exe when they receive an auto update, or will the hash not match error?

Read full topic
